Provided the wind is not blowing
Too strongly. That's crazy?
But no, our group's lazy
And simply do not like hard going.

limerick_list.author: birdbarf
limerick_list.text:
Wanna buy a stuffed goat with one eye?
Or a coat made of lint?  I'm your guy.
I'm a cheapjack, a dealer
In crap, like this peeler,
Just one ninety-nine—what a buy!

limerick_list.author: Andrew Burnet
limerick_list.text:
"To be," mused Prince Hamlet, "or not?
Should I give this life one final shot,
Or obey Death's sweet call?
(One swift pang ends it all.)
That's a question I've pondered a lot."

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
At the Cabinet meeting today,
Let's make fun of Dick Cheney. What say
We start gasping for air
And then slump in the chair
When he opens his yapper, okay?

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
What a baby face! Scowl was so cute
That it caused my relentless pursuit
Of that child-featured miss!
I did not get a kiss:
Scowl the Owl blew me off with one hoot.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The apothecary down on the square
Is the place to buy drugs for your care;
And the pharmacist's neat
'Cause he likes to repeat
All the gossip on who, what, and where.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Our great country's divided in twain,
Split in two by the madmen who reign.
Let's build that tall wall
That will separate all
Those sad crazies from those who are sane.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
There's no need for your dire apprehension.
We've a star who grabs public attention.
She's a drawing card, so
I'm convinced that our show
Will win gold at the Boy Scouts' convention.

limerick_list.author: Michael Daws
limerick_list.text:
Beasts like bison and deer form a clade —
A unique common ancestor made
Both distinct from the cat
(Though I'm not certain that
We could find it without a big spade).

limerick_list.author: David Schildkret
limerick_list.text:
Upon meeting a late debauchee,
Old St. Peter accosts him with glee.
For his fun with the ladies,
Pete sends him to Hades:
For sin has a cost, don't you see?

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
The carpospore, what is it for?
To tell you the truth, I'm not sure.
It's not quite a germ,
Or a worm, or a sperm,
But I know it helps algae make more.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Big Ben watches while bobbies patrol
Where the ranks of swank bank gents all stroll.
The Embankment now hems in
The flanks of the Thames in
Old haunts of Toad, Ratty and Mole.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
William Spooner went fishing and took
Both the Bible and worms to the brook.
First he blessed them (he read
From Hosea), then said,
"Now it's time to be hating the book."

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
That line about "...two in the bush"
Comes to mind when we're tempted to push
Toward a riskier goal
That might take a large toll.
Better keep this soft job that's so cush.

limerick_list.author: Colin Salter
limerick_list.text:
The Victorians noted with clarity,
In the Lower Class, moral disparity.
The deserving they knew,
And the criminal too;
Only one was thought worthy of charity.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
A pine needle needled a cone
In a "hey-deedle-deedle"-ish tone.
This acerose nettling
The cone found unsettling
And sighed a lugubrious groan.

limerick_list.author: Robert Holland
limerick_list.text:
Hair of gold ... I was hers to command.
Such enchantment no man could withstand.
I have memories fond
Of this "suicide blonde"
Who dyed by her very own hand.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Your complaints are too hopeless and soapy; yuh
Will miss a great feast. Don't be mopey; yuh
Can go off on a spree;
This buffet table's free.
Of great food it's a true cornucopia.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
It was clear that our chances weren't great,
And to finish dead last was our fate.
Still, the fault lies with me,
Not my horse. The Grand Prix
I had entered some hundred years late.

limerick_list.author: Jonathan Caws-Elwitt
limerick_list.text:
It's a form of elliptical speaking
To end with "and all." If you're seeking
The same sort of tone
For which Caulfield is known,
Use this phrase. (Be prepared for critiquing.)

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Should your favorite saint up and die,
Quickly dig up a bone from her thigh.
Holy relics for healing
Are wholly appealing—
So there's rarely a goodly supply.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Your lexicon, now, I'll increase
With a word that I find to be dece,
Though it's slang. It means "fine."
Spell it dees, that's divine,
As the joys of our speech never cease.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
My friend, in our panto, is great
As an emu, but takes his cues late.
His lines he starts missing;
The children start hissing.
Our late emu don't emulate, mate!

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
I'm in love, which has rotted my brain.
But I'll say it again and again:
Though you don't look so glamorous,
You make me feel amorous—
Say, garbage man, am I insane?

limerick_list.author: geniuswaitress
limerick_list.text:
All the gals at the country club sneer
When they see their poor waitress appear.
They're so cliquish and clubbish
And treat her like rubbish,
Which is why she just spat in their beer.

limerick_list.author: Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
Dave Bing received numerous cheers—
His was one of the greatest careers.
As a guard for Detroit,
He was fast and adroit,
Making marvelous plays for nine years.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
For some foodies Bourdain stood alone.
His fame stretched from Beirut to the Rhône.
His sad end all regret.
His next stop, you can bet,
Will be new. As to where: Parts Unknown.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The bobsledders push at the top
As they sprint to the edge of the drop.
Then they zoom down the ice
And ignore a device
Called the brake, 'cause they know they can't stop.

limerick_list.author: timon
limerick_list.text:
His sudden cry filled me with dread:
"True evils, those, there in the bread!
For collectors, a bonny day —
Curculionidae!"
(Then I grasp that it's "weevils" he said.)

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Was my brother unfortunate? Very!
He believed in "eat, drink, and be merry!"
He stayed drunk and got fat,
So remarkably that
He's the first that we needed to bury.

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
If a reindeer and caribou mated,
The term for the offspring created
Would be carideer, though
All our poll results show
The term reinbou is much higher-rated.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
A geology major in Boulder
Got mad when a rock outlet sold her
"Derivative rocks"
(So they said), but the box
Held not deuterogenic, but older.

limerick_list.author: Comicoffee
limerick_list.text:
"Where's your brother?" Mom asked at the table.
"I dunno, Ma. You checked by the stable?"
"Cain, account for his whereabouts!"
"Try Egypt or thereabouts.
The exact place? Can't say—I'm not Abel."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Twenty-fifth of December: that's when
Ancient Greeks held a festival. Then
Later Roman displays
Lasted thirty-odd days.
Think Brumalia will come back again?

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
Since it's honesty folk are demanding,
To the press, all my sexploits I'm handing.
Will the voters respect me?
They ought to elect me:
The candidest candidate standing.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
Dyscalculia gets me all mad:
It's so hard to subtract or to add.
On a test: 4 x 4 ____
I wrote "Truck." Teacher swore.
Now I'm tutored in math by my dad.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan and StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
This champagne is  trop doux (that's too sweet),
And Claude whines, "It's a knock-off—a cheat,"
But for what we both earn
Only rotgut Sauterne
Is  à vendre in measures petite.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
It's a Fibber McGee's closet in there:
Mounds of rummage and no room to spare.
One particular stack
Looks prepared to attack.
It's been growling and shifting—I swear!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
It's a drug many sluggers abuse—
Known as andro (for short) in the news.
Androstenedione's bad!
Barry Bonds used a scad;
Now he's sluggish and singing the blues.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
The family bills were a blight,
And he often lost sleep in the night;
But the sight of his son
Running round, full of fun,
Shouting, "Daddy!" made everything right.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Those old-timey docs knew what's what:
"An aperient cleanses the gut.
Black draught and blue pills
Can prevent many ills
In the springtime. It's open and shut."

limerick_list.author: Andrew Burnet
limerick_list.text:
Cockney rhyming slang, jargon of vendors:
An argot of manifold splendours.
It works by allusion
And might cause confusion
To overseas fans of EastEnders.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The First Lady, in Washington lore,
In a shipwreck we shouldn't ignore.
Claim the harbor police,
If she's greatly obese,
She could FLOTUS all safely to shore.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
I don't care what you think that it says,
This small city does not rhyme with fez.
If you're living out there,
It is clearly "Des Peres."
Only outsiders say "Des Peres."

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
A shy and diminutive chow
Felt unable to bow, far less wow.
Then he scored a cool bitch
(Knowing Master was rich).
He's top dog in the neighbourhood now.

limerick_list.author: Dave Jermy
limerick_list.text:
That we'd win wasn't looking in doubt,
Then our bowlers created a rout.
We had posted four-fifty;
Their reply? Not so nifty —
Just one hundred and twenty all out.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
A crackerjack con in Sudan
Handcrafted crude shanks in the can.
He made use of his shank craft
To fix a cracked crankshaft,
Then split in the warden's old van.

limerick_list.author: stella
limerick_list.text:
Snapweed thrives on wet streambanks and creeks,
In the dampness that bitter cress seeks.
Aphids relish these weeds,
Which propel wingless seeds
From dehiscent, dry seedpods (siliques).

limerick_list.author: alan meyer
limerick_list.text:
An almond's the nut of a tree,
A storehouse of vitamin E.
Seven calories in each,
And if they're within reach
You'll gobble them watching TV.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Playing chess is a difficult thing.
To be honest, I'd rather play ping-
pong or poker. What proves
That I don't know the moves?
I'm confused about castling my king.

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
The full orchestra isn't arrayed
To perform Strauss's fine serenade.
With some strings and four horns—
Woodwinds, too—it adorns
Every symphony hall where it's played.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin and Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
My friend Atticus claims Bora Bora
Has delightful assortments of flora.
The blossoms gals wear
Gaily twined in their hair
Make him constantly shout, "More-a! More-a!"

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Your old man was a crook, and I see
That the nut falls not far from the tree.
You exhibit the traits
Of your father.  The Fates
Say no use should you try to break free.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
The wet tea leaves mount up with each strainerful
Until I've achieved a containerful.
But recyclers reject
What I've strained to collect:
"It's non-compost." What's meant is: no-brainerful.

limerick_list.author: Dave Jermy
limerick_list.text:
How I wish I'd decided to warn her,
As I bowled to a batsman called Horner.
Didn't think he'd be able
To hit poor old Mabel
As she munched on the grass in cow corner.

limerick_list.author: OldFitzer
limerick_list.text:
Many women, I hear, are impressed
By some hair on a big manly chest.
But such hair, I suggest,
They abhor and detest,
When it grows on their womanly breast.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
They are creepy! They're crawly! They're gross!
I would rather they didn't come close!
They commit heinous crimes
In my lemons and limes—
Citrus mealybugs make me morose!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin and zqms
limerick_list.text:
A fluther, a swarm, or a smack
Are all jellyfish found in a pack.
When nouns are collective,
Avoid the defective:
No terms such as fluther of yak.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
You're a black-hearted, venomous hack, mister—
And you? You're a stab in the back, sister.
So what if I'm red?
Least my conscience ain't dead—
By Stalin's mustache, I'm no blacklister!

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
To be in with your mates as a lad
You would join in a craze or a fad;
You swapped stickers (you'd stacks
Saved from bubble gum packs).
Looking back, such obsession seems mad.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When your yacht has just made a distress call,
You hope that your loud SOS call
Brings aid right away,
So the captain can say:
"That distress call was sure a success call!"

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Johnny C had just fleeting renown
But was dubbed "The Fantastic."  His crown
Had one jewel: he lit
Up two charts with a hit.
It was Broadway he boogalooed down.

limerick_list.author: Jeff Russell
limerick_list.text:
My lover was terribly quarrelly.
I made my complaint to her orally:
"Would you quit—for Pete's sake—it?
How far can you take it?"
So she showed how far, ambulatorily.

limerick_list.author: Qermaq
limerick_list.text:
My friend said to me, of the Army,
"The drill sergeants feather and tar me!
A conflict I pray fer!
I think I'd be safer—
My own are more likely to harm me!"

limerick_list.author: Partypoet
limerick_list.text:
Two Yalies imbibed in a pub;
Its name was Ye Olde Drinking Club.
When I asked, "Howya feeling?"
They answered me, reeling,
"We've beer cans galore, but no grub!"

limerick_list.author: Giorgio Coniglio
limerick_list.text:
While decipherin' VLADIMIR PUTIN,
Might one learn of an asset's recruitin'?
U.S. Intel was ruffled
'Til letters got shuffled
To INVALID: I, TRUMP. No refutin'.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Sonny, government notes," said my pa,
"Are what weekly I give to yer ma.
Those are banknotes, y'see,
As is 'cash,' not re, mi,
Fa, ti, la, only 'dough!' (Ha-Ha-Ha!)"

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
I'm a vampire, and don't think I'm griping;
A and B from my teeth I am wiping.
But what leaves me aglow
Is when virgins shriek: "O!"
Then I go (with the flow) — that's blood-typing.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
"It's better to give than to get":
Words of Jesus, I'm willing to bet.
But wouldn't you know it?
The Gospels don't show it.
They're part of the agrapha set.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
Bulwer-Lytton wrote tales oft retold
'Bout a Round Table hero, so bold:
He, with skin black as coal,
And with rage in his soul
Was a dark stormy knight to behold.

limerick_list.author: stella
limerick_list.text:
A console can house all the switches
Connecting the thingummy, which is
Controlling the flights
Of rockets, or lights
So that movies can run without glitches.

limerick_list.author: neilski
limerick_list.text:
London traffic's frustratingly poor —
Something has to be done, that's for sure!
But we won't get to see
Ringway 1, 2 or 3:
Just a bus lane upon the M4.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
At the ice rink there's light and there's sound—
To the show, that's the way folks are bound.
The main players are kings:
Each one dances and sings,
While the chorus skates round and around.

limerick_list.author: waterrocks
limerick_list.text:
A cross is a mix we festoon
With a combo of features — a boon.
For example, the spork
Teams the stab of a fork
With the elegant scoop of a spoon.

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
Gallinaceans take meals on the ground
While their cousins are flying around.
Gallinaceous birds swear
That it's nicer down there,
And it's where they're primarily found.

limerick_list.author: Kevin
limerick_list.text:
Disendowment—my aunt took away
The endowment she'd made me one day.
Her reason was simple:
The fun of her pimple
I'd made to her utter dismay.

limerick_list.author: Robert Holland
limerick_list.text:
At times, we must all take a stand
In a crisis that forces our hand.
We can't pass through this life
Without woes, without strife,
But a failure, though sad, can be grand.

limerick_list.author: Meg Beagle
limerick_list.text:
Alumni of Ivy League schools
Are not often thought of as fools,
But reading the dailies
Makes me doubt about Yalies,
Who may have their own set of rules.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
I'm an egghead (a real brainy bloke) 'n'
You've asked me if, by the same token,
Are folk in ol' Mensa
(The intelligents'a)
The eggmass?  You bet. I ain't yolkin'.

limerick_list.author: Type A
limerick_list.text:
"That man is ahorse," said Ms. Marr.
"No way!" I replied. "That's bizarre.
That rider, of course,
Is a man. That's the horse.
Next you'll tell me that door is a jar."

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
G means "grand" as a trailing addition.
GA: gamblers in search of remission.
Gal: a femme, doll or skirt.
Gale: a wind that can hurt.
Galen: healer and ancient physician.

limerick_list.author: turnip
limerick_list.text:
The anomalist Greeks felt  a word —
Be it kumquat or dingdong or bird —
Had no meaning attached,
But was randomly hatched.
The analogists said, "That's absurd!"

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
With exploitable resources here,
We'll extract them for many a year.
There is oil in the ground,
Plus the iron we found.
We'll deplete them and then disappear.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
For small chunks (choosing ten loci, say)
List the bases of found DNA;
Match that DNA profile
To a someone-you-know file
And you may get the perp put away.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A conjecture by Lewis and Trautz
That our chemistry lecturer spouts:
"The theory (collision)
Explains with precision
Reactions of compounds." I've doubts.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Tobacco inspector Dan Hiller
Broke a section and found little filler.
Then the hogshead, they said,
Rolled and crushed the man's head.
Yes, tobacco, it's true, is a killer.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
With your shovels, platoon, you must cram
These warm slops, down to every last gram,
In this one million litre
(Each dimension ten metre)
Hole: cubic hot diggity dam!

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
In a cathode ray tube, coatings wrap
Round the glass.  Aquadag helps to trap
Stray electrons and slow
Any spikeage in flow.
(It's not "fish poo"; that's cod-derived crap.)

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
Mum grew feeble in Scotland; she'd dotter.
Art Prof Margaret (painter and potter)
Left her post in the States.
She and Philip—they're mates—
Bought a cottage near Mum:  Prof's a cotter.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Wilhelmina was willowy, stately;
Her behavior was formal, innately.
Although John was a comer,
She judged him a bummer—
An upstart, a Johnny-come-lately.

limerick_list.author: Meg Beagle
limerick_list.text:
Afternoons are the best time of day.
I eat, then I rest, then I play.
I sit out on the chaise
And I happily gaze
At all that is passing my way.

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
The next tetherball game that you play,
Try impressing your friends when you say,
"The centripetal force
Keeps the ball on its course
And prevents it from flying away."

limerick_list.author: Jean McEwen
limerick_list.text:
I store plasma and tissue and pee,
And I serve as a kind of trustee
For samples so rare
That they need special care.
I'm a biobank—run for a fee.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Benny Bell was a tunesmith with wit,
Though he only had one major hit.
It's a classic, however.
You don't think it's clever?
My response is that you're full of shhhhaving cream!

limerick_list.author: waterrocks
limerick_list.text:
You're terse: sometimes brusque, sometimes blunt.
You don't waffle. You rarely confront
Any issue digressing
From what you're addressing.
But conciseness does not mean a grunt!

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
To ramble, to roam or to stray,
Or even to wander away;
These obsolete meanings
From dictionary gleanings
Bring err to the folks of today.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
A cathedra (from Greek for "sit down")
Is a throne where no king wears a crown.
Its appointed alighter,
A bishop, dons mitre
(And quite the most sumptuous gown).

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I bought stock on a tip: "You can't beat it!"
Got a margin call — sold stock to meet it.
That caused a huge loss
For my firm; the big boss
Said, "I'm sorry, son — you'll have to eat it."

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
When an adjective's impact's impeded,
And intensification is needed,
Just appending an -ass
Adds momentum and mass,
And your good-ass expression's succeeded!

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
For protection from Jimmy's rude goose,
I'm wearing a long, loose burnoose.
The wide robe spikes his guns
By hiding my buns.
(The hood I leave down — it's not spruce.)

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
When distressed (that's "perturbed") what I do
Is paint walls in a bright yellow hue.
But pup Fang, acting smart,
Bumped the can off the cart.
Now that lemon collie's melancholy too.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"I have cubitus valgus," said Chip,
"And my forearm points out from my hip.
It's a different deformity,
But to me no enormity.
I think brother Jared's a drip!"

limerick_list.author: pöt
limerick_list.text:
The Belgians: In Belgium they dwell,
Where there's Brussels, and Ghent, and Nivelles.
The people speak Flemish
Or French without blemish.
In the east, they speak German as well.

limerick_list.author: Cuttlefish
limerick_list.text:
New-age mystics are making us slaves
To our EEG readings, the knaves!
It's not hocus-pocus
But mere lack of focus
That seems to produce alpha waves.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
There's a new aboriginal crew
That's refinishing pipes of bamboo.
They work hard on the task
Till the boss comes to ask,
"So how many here didgeridoo?"

limerick_list.author: DavidGries
limerick_list.text:
Now doesn't catholicate sound
Like a verb that's mistakenly nouned?
But a noun is its niche;
It's the region in which
A catholicos bosses around.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
If the Mafia thinks you're a rat:
Cement shoes; glub, glub, glub; and that's that.
If they're really upset
Then you might also get
Cement underwear, pants, and a hat.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Uncle Stan liked the Barleycorn.  Pop
Says, "Malt liquor in hand was his prop
All too often.  Our clan
Likes to drink, but ol' Stan,
Rest in peace, didn't know when to stop."

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Did you know your TV is a spy?
You didn't? Well, neither did I.
Its "smart" snooping goes far
Thanks to dark ACR
You can maybe turn off, if you try.

limerick_list.author: Nitelaf
limerick_list.text:
In The Case of the Wandering Rhino,
The detective, a strapping albino,
Finds the gate of the zoo
To be bent and askew.
Does the rhino escape?  Hell if I know...

limerick_list.author: Paperdragon
limerick_list.text:
These begin with a generous suck,
Then a squeeze makes a bang! with some luck.
With a blow it all ends.
Diesel engines, my friends,
Have no spark plugs (I'm not writing muck).

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
One's a song, one's a guy, then there's teen
Trou of choice, or may happen to mean
Genetic material
That even some cereal
Can contain this quite harmless blue gene.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Think it's newsworthy? I disagree:
It's a story that no one need see.
I know gossip's delicious,
But this is plain vicious.
We'll bury it—page twenty-three.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
I'm a single conservative, mate,
And I'm picky about whom I'll date.
So if we should dine,
I'll decline to drink wine,
And you must have me home before eight.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
One will find that wherever one looks,
Bibliopegists seldom are crooks.
They work hard every day
At their craft so they may
Make a living by binding our books.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
A buntin (plump) butt I have sought.
Yes, I did what I shouldn't have ought:
I looked outside for that.
Your bum's saggy and flat!
I am so sorry, dear. I got caught!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Black locust's the kind of a tree
That's familiar as coffee or tea—
Not a plague that would harrow
The Biblical pharaoh—
The tree whose first cousin's a pea.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
A magazine known for soft porn
Was called Argosy, often reborn
Into new incarnations
Of pulp publications;
Enjoyed — or regarded with scorn.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Dreadnought was cloth made of wool,
That was used to sew jackets, cut full,
Or the garment itself
That you'd take off the shelf,
Stick your arms in, and give it a pull.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The hardware store clerk would appear
To be quite hard of hearing, I fear.
"It's a bug light I need."
He looked puzzled indeed,
Then returned with a cold can of beer.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
For my son, deep emotion is writable,
And his poetry's notably citable.
Known throughout the U.K.,
He's much quoted today,
So I'm hoping my scion is knightable.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
When you dress à la mode, you are chic
And belong to the toniest clique.
You exhibit a passion
For trendy high fashion.
But me? I'm a Gucci-less geek.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Take a jellyfish, then take another,
Then two more, maybe sister and brother.
Keep it up and then soon
The whole beach will be strewn
With a group of these things, called a fluther.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
If the concept of foreordination
Means it's pointless to strive for salvation,
Destination pre-charted,
Each lately departed,
Prayers aside, may descend to damnation.

limerick_list.author: equinox
limerick_list.text:
Cybercrime: acts of a scammer
On the Net, like a phisher or spammer,
Or a teen who plays pranks
On the Internet banks.
(Can he hack his way out of the slammer?)

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
Inner Harbor is host to the throng.
Water taxis and cars speed along,
Bearing people to play
Amid scents of Old Bay:
Busy Baltimore's still going strong.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
An arithmetician I know,
Good at Go (good enough to go pro),
With a grin laughs away
My reluctance to play,
"It's like sex: easy come, easy Go."

limerick_list.author: pkwooster
limerick_list.text:
Debunking is sport on the Net.
The experts won't let you forget
Your citing Petronius,
Which they say is erroneous,
In that paper you've come to regret.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When I'm rich (at the moment, I'm poor),
I'll indulge in expensive couture.
My couturier, Che,
I will visit each day,
Buying clothing while sipping liqueur.

limerick_list.author: Tom Foolery
limerick_list.text:
Betty Mae sings a daily aubade;
That's a greeting, a musical nod
To the morn (but not quite,
'Cause she sings it at night,
Which is more than a little bit odd).

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A five-year-old tomboy and scamp
Took gymnastics one year at a camp.
On the floor and the beam
She was living a dream:
The Olympic and all-around champ.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
For this latest admission, our fee
Will be minimal. He was F-D-
S-T-W. Look
On the bright side: this schnook
From all paying of bills now is free.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
What? You don't know enough to disguise
Your delight at a rival's  demise?
I surmise: when one dies,
You wave smiling goodbyes
As he closes his eyes.  Is that wise?

limerick_list.author: pkwooster
limerick_list.text:
An Airedale's a large furry beast
That hunts otters, a small tasty feast.
They're wiry and wooly,
And often will bully.
They're dogs that our poodle likes least.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"All my friends do it!"  Mom replies: "If
They all jumped, would you leap from a cliff?
Don't play follow the leader!"
I decided to heed her,
And thus we avoided a tiff.

limerick_list.author: woodfostersmith
limerick_list.text:
When I ordered, the bartender said,
"You want Amer Picon?" — scratched his head.
"Orange bitters with gentian?
It's too rare to mention!
I'll use Angostura instead."

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
Broken light from small droplets that grew
In the morn makes a colorful view!
All the bladelets of grass
Carry "diamonds"—of glass?—
No, of water, reliquefied: dew!

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
A block is a segment of track
With a signal so trains don't go "Smack."
The signal will show
When to stop or to go
(Assuming it's not out of whack).

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
There's a challenge that prickles your hair
If the enemy's lines you would dare
Reconnoitre to seek
Any points that are weak.
It's a voice saying, "Halt! Who goes there?!"

limerick_list.author: Steve Ngai
limerick_list.text:
Count your equal-sized chromosome factions
That result from meiotic cell actions.
Any integer's fine.
They're called euploid: good sign!
But you're aneuploid when you get fractions.

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
Baby Jane now weighs three-point-three pounds.
She can breathe off the vent (within bounds).
So a bath basin's set
In her warm isolette
For the baby's first bath—and first sounds.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
When designing maternity clothes,
Don't allow the couture to impose
Too much style over room,
'Cause when moms-to-be bloom,
Mother-frockers, they can't see their toes!

limerick_list.author: Meg Beagle
limerick_list.text:
My complexion went thoroughly ashen.
Would anyone show some compassion?
Could I show my grey face
In a haute couture place
Without wearing the latest in fashion?

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Constitutional fixes? Complex!
Twenty-seven to date on the decks.
The 19th, we should note,
Gave the distaff the vote.
That amendment contains the word sex.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
The words of the song are appealing
And those high notes you hold reach the ceiling,
Yet you sing it so blandly!
Try again, but more grandly,
Emotionally: once more with feeling!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
What's electoral? Any connection
Or allusion to any election,
Like the voters' cross section,
Or the outcome projection,
Or the poll-watchers' loyal protection.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
"I-I'm sorry. Perhaps the word's spread?
You've not heard? Then it has be said ...
It's not easy, b-but ..."
She falteringly stut-
tered, "I'm sad to t-tell you — he's dead."

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
While boastfully brimming with pride,
The braggart kept swelling inside.
But with no one to tell,
He continued to swell
'Til he suddenly burst—and he died.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
If your dwelling looks drab to your mind,
Reupholster your chairs. You will find
That the fabric chenille
Has a velvety feel
That appeals to your tender behind.

limerick_list.author: LMAK
limerick_list.text:
Each cell will cry out with this plea:
We need energy, ample and free!
Respiration (aerobic,
Not oxygen phobic)
Burns glucose to make ATP.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"Pesky a's slipping in," howled Ed Powell.
"Let's disclaim them—don't throw in the towel.
Only fools will write aegis
Seeking honor prestigious!"
That's Powell's supreme disavowal.

limerick_list.author: David Roberts and Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
A tune was once played by a cat;
Someone yelled, "You should orchestrate that!"
The poor cat misheard it,
And, laying a turd, it
Defenestrated itself and went splat.

limerick_list.author: Kirk Zurell
limerick_list.text:
My wife, bargain hunter, pursues
Her quarry by tracking the clues:
Flocks of flyers take flight;
Discount posters invite
Her to flush out boutiques full of shoes!

limerick_list.author: hwindle
limerick_list.text:
I love clothespins, so useful yet plain,
Made of hardwood and crafted in Maine.
They hold wash on the line
When the weather is fine.
(If I'm careless, at times too in rain.)

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The disease that is known as Devic's
We see more in Chinese than in Greeks.
It displays great unkindness—
Paralysis, blindness—
In peaks and may last many weeks.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
My pooch found a box in the park,
Raised the lid, and then started to bark.
The container was lead.
("Cobalt 60" it read.)
To my dread, he now glows in the dark.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Never shy when approaching a dame,
Dave moves forwardly, taking good aim.
Should she say he's too bold,
He won't quit; he won't fold.
Free of shame, he'll continue the game.

limerick_list.author: SusanL and oneslowtyper
limerick_list.text:
There's a place in Montana called Butte
Where old miners dropped bundles of loot.
This Superfund pit's
Giving tree huggers fits—
Though the brothel's of highest repute!

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
"You're a hairy, ill-mannered buffoon.
I'd suggest you try changing your tune."
"Your candor's impressive.
I may seem excessive,
But my bearishness makes women swoon."

limerick_list.author: Carl Lands
limerick_list.text:
"He who takes the next town weds my daughter,"
Said Caleb—so Othniel got her.
Not a layabout lass,
Achsah got off her ass
And demanded some land that had water.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
I'm knocked out by a girl at the pool
Who's been blessed with, I'd say, every tool:
Killer face (big brown eyes),
Killer bod (oh, those thighs),
And a smile that could bring down a mule.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
Milking cows is the job I like best
On my farm in Wisconsin's midwest.
While I dream about cheese,
I have udders to squeeze—
Dairy farming just makes me feel blessed.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
When shopping for meat, I have seen
That what's red is expensive. I mean,
If your main concern's price,
You should take my advice:
Choose the older stuff—go for the green!

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Would-be actresses, might I suggest
That the casting director is best
Who rates how you act
By your style, not the fact
That you have or have not a big chest.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
A. abrotanum: let me make clear
That this wormwood makes worms disappear.
When prepared as a potion
For bowel commotion,
It leads to that hearty bronx cheer.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
I've far less spare time than I'd reckoned:
My mom will be here in a second;
And I have to get cracking
On college-bound packing —
And canning (my garden is fecund).

limerick_list.author: creelbm
limerick_list.text:
In the Acts of Apostles, Paul's trip:
King Agrippa put Paul on a ship.
Adramyttium's port
Was the start of his short
Jaunt to Rome, just a hop, jump and skip.

limerick_list.author: Aliza
limerick_list.text:
A Nantucket guitarist named Max
Played some rip-roaring licks on his axe.
Backed by Becky on 'boards,
These thundering chords
Got the crowds buying stacks of his tracks.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
They spoke diffidently, modest and shy,
To the morning and noon passers-by,
As they stretched out their palms,
Pleading softly for alms—
And their diffidence made people cry.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
There once was a Japanese jockey
Whose home was in Amagasaki,
But he found that his horse
Couldn't keep to the course,
"So perhaps," he declared, "I'll try hockey."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
I'd say fugler is one of those words
That, because of its first half, to nerds
Seems suggestive of what
It's most certainly not.
It's a catcher or keeper of birds.

limerick_list.author: Dave Jermy
limerick_list.text:
The wicket looked perfectly flat.
As eleven, I thought I'd be sat
There all day. Then some flaps
Caused a batting collapse —
Nine men out — so I went in to bat.

limerick_list.author: EdRush
limerick_list.text:
The penalty now? Durance vile!
They torture him, too, all the while!
In a prison he sits,
Just for loosing some bits
Of memos in Wikileaks style.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Let us expertise research today —
Tell the amateurs, "Please go away!"
The Board has okayed
More professional aid —
No more fooling around, guys! OK?

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
There's a dwarf and a geezer that spar,
Each a very close binary star.
When the dwarf steals the covers,
These quarrelsome lovers
Blow up, and it's seen from afar.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Empanadas are turnovers, Fred —
Very varied.  Wrap soft, flat white bread
Round a filling of meat,
Or sweet fruit, for a treat;
Bake or fry. Muy sabroso! Nuff said.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
It was clear that our marriage was toast.
To a dalliance or two I'd been host.
Maybe three.  Perhaps four.
Maybe seven or more.
OK, fifteen or twenty, at most!

limerick_list.author: Giri
limerick_list.text:
In my office IT, there's a guy
Who aspired to ascend very high,
But his temper was flighty,
And he dissed someone mighty.
Now he's screwed; his career's end is nigh.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
When a patient or family goes nuts,
Code Secure calls the guys who've got guts.
If you're violent, folks,
Swift response this provokes.
Watch security come kick your butts.

limerick_list.author: Mark Mironer
limerick_list.text:
My caffeine addiction's severe;
Can't live without coffee, that's clear.
I explain with a shrug
As I empty my mug:
"The morning comes early round here."

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
Playing halma, just two (maybe four)
Clever strategists lay down the law.
For two more, there's a game
That is somewhat the same:
Chinese checkers — which I find a bore.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Swedish meatballs? I love them, of course.
What? They're made not of beef, but of horse?
I thought horsemeat was banned.
I object, I demand:
Common Market, I want a divorce!

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
A whinny from Winnie the Horse
Is a verse we're averse to endorse,
As her meter and rhyme
Fail to scan half the time.
Does she versify? Nay. Neigh, of course.

limerick_list.author: Taillefer
limerick_list.text:
My eulogium tells you, "You are
An unparalleled, praiseworthy star
Of our verse-writing crowd.
Your craft makes us so proud—
You are one of the greatest by far."

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
"Eloign!" yelled Eileen at Elaine.
"Learn to leave me alone. You're a pain.
Can't you see (you're so blind!)
We're no longer aligned?
Pack your bags. Take a hike. Catch a plane."

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
A bill's how the pelican feeds—
How the helican store all he needs.
But it's also the beak
Of which botanists speak:
A projecting appendage to seeds.

limerick_list.author: Doug Aldridge
limerick_list.text:
To batten means simply to fatten.
It's your bod?  Well, at least take a statin.
But a greater offense?
Wealth at others' expense.
(Yet, I do love my sheets of rich satin.)

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
A teen who's, like, totally able
To drive his mom's Mercury Sable
Without harming a fly
Just can't wait to defy
An insurer's statistical table.

limerick_list.author: Chaiwallah
limerick_list.text:
As Rob Roy sallied forth with his men
To drive the Brits out of the glen,
From his sporran and kilt
To his sword's basket hilt,
He looked like a hero, back then.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Rare gemstones so finely engraved
He amassed and eternally craved,
Says this latest biography.
Antique dactyliography
Was the art by which Sam was enslaved.

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
The beauties of whom we have read
In Byron and Shakespeare are dead,
But Calverley found
More dependable ground
When he glorified beer brands instead.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
I've lived this damn lush life for days.
I expense it; the company pays.
Still, I'm forced to dine well
In the firm's choice hotel
With my clients. This merits a raise.

limerick_list.author: kandabongo
limerick_list.text:
Red hot Yuri soon felt some regret:
He had married an ex-pat coquette.
She was not anti-Russian,
But every discussion
She ended quite forcefully: "Nyet!"

limerick_list.author: Qermaq
limerick_list.text:
Oh, the accent in music, it looks
Like a V that was knocked down by crooks.
What it says? "Hit me hard!
I don't care if I'm scarred!
The composer intends it, you schnooks!"

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Sing hickory, dickory, dockery:
The sink's full of soap suds and crockery.
Take care washing up
Every plate, dish and cup —
Don't want broken ceramics through knockery!

limerick_list.author: J. E. Pettit
limerick_list.text:
"You should probably get with the times;
Buy a TV in color," he chimes.
So I answer with, "Why?
I'm a black-and-white guy,
Plus I'm cheap with my nickels and dimes."

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
Rooting pigs simply can't cope without
An assessing, inquisitive snout.
You could, if you chose to,
Judge mud with your nose, too,
But, goodness, you'd look like a lout!

limerick_list.author: Paperdragon
limerick_list.text:
Bundaegi are chrysalis meat;
Silkworm pupae are cooked up to eat.
I'm reluctant to munch
Some dead insects for lunch
So it's dog soup for me, down the street.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
All this scratching is no bed of roses.
My skin's got dermatomycosis.
Doc's careful inspection
Shows fungal infection:
A dermatophyte's his diagnosis.

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
He's a gonif, a thief, and a crook!
You recall all the stuff that he took?
If he says that he'll buy,
Then he's telling a lie
'Cause his checks bounce. Don't trust him, you schnook.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Here's a fish that is now booed and hissed,
Since it doesn't, and didn't, exist.
Quite respectable tomes
Said the blue roach's homes
Were in Swiss lakes and Knowsley. Dismissed.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Do your cows become ill and abort,
So you fear that your herd will be short?
The vet's diagnosis:
Acute brucellosis,
Or Bang's disease, says his report.

limerick_list.author: Bluebelle
limerick_list.text:
Going round in a circle I found
That my circular trail would abound
With continuous curves
And long, drawn-out swerves,	
Till I started again… going round…

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
Go to school?  Do my chores?  That's so lame.
I'm content with the dud I became.
So, I ride on my scooter
And cruise my computer.
Escapism — yeah, that's my game.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Guard her privacy? This Gail will do
With a vengeance. It's clear only Sue,
In the cottage next door,
Knows her secrets. (They're more
Than just friends, if the rumors are true.)

limerick_list.author: jexia
limerick_list.text:
Vaccinations are never a cinch
But I'll get them, and not give an inch.
I will be courageous,
Though fear is contagious;
I'll face them with nary a flinch.

limerick_list.author: S. A. McBurnie
limerick_list.text:
Her hair is both silky and curly;
Her figure, decidedly girly.
But what ruins it all
For the fellows who fall
Is her attitude: grumpy and surly.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
Our town's population has grown,
And its lack of respect is well-known.
Cultural pluralism? No.
Racial tolerance? Low—
And so each of us fends for our own.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
We'd a whole lot of folks taking naps;
The result was the Wall Street collapse.
Now we're stuck with the bill,
Which is nearly a tril.
We share blame; we elect the same saps.

limerick_list.author: stella
limerick_list.text:
Mr Wolfie was hungry, not happy;
To the piggy, he said, "Hey there, chappie!
You're a chubby wee chap.
Come and sit in my lap."
Then, chomping his chaps, "Make it snappy!"

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
"Here's proof," said a smooth politician.
"The data confirms my position."
His cherry-picked portion
Creates a distortion —
The truth hid by sins of omission.

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
A fossil collector in search
Of new specimens, left in the lurch
Having found no old bones
That had turned into stones,
Went collecting instead for the church.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
It was easy for me to predict
That your story and mine would conflict.
I object, disaffirm,
Contradict you—you worm!
You may lie, but I cannot be tricked.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
Said the faith healer, "Folks, let us  pray
To our God: Make this blight go away.
Yes, dear Lord, we all beg
That you fix his broke leg
And remove gangrened tissue today."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A canoness, just like a canon
Who's regular, lives in a clan, 'n'
She's taken the vows
That her order allows—
Now she lives where they won't let a man in.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A carpel's a part of a pistil.
A carpal? That bone in your wrist'll
Help steer when you drive
In the carpool with five
Of your buddies each morning to Bristol.

text: This is a test to see how well you are paying attention. This text is a series of limericks. At the end of the list of limericks, there will be a question. The question will be about one of the limericks. Please answer the question as concisely as possible.
